parts: Please recommend books that cover mathematical statistics, inferential and bayesian statistics

Here’s a set of well-regarded books that together cover the breadth and depth of **mathematical statistics**, **classical inference**, and **Bayesian statistics**, from graduate-level theory to applied perspectives. I’ve grouped them by primary emphasis so you can structure your reading path.

---

## 1. Mathematical Statistics (Rigorous Foundations)

**Casella, George & Berger, Roger L. – *Statistical Inference***  
A gold-standard graduate-level text. Rigorous treatment of probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, likelihood methods, and asymptotics. Strong proofs and exercises. Excellent bridge between probability theory and applied inference.

**Bickel, Peter J. & Doksum, Kjell A. – *Mathematical Statistics: Basic Ideas and Selected Topics* (Vols. I & II)**  
More measure-theoretic than Casella–Berger. Includes asymptotic theory, exponential families, robustness, and semiparametric inference. Volume II ventures into more advanced territory.

**Lehmann, E. L. & Casella, George – *Theory of Point Estimation* / *Testing Statistical Hypotheses***  
Two separate but complementary classics, with a highly rigorous and comprehensive approach to the core theory of estimation and hypothesis testing. The proofs are meticulous, and these are definitive references for mathematical statisticians.

**van der Vaart, Aad W. – *Asymptotic Statistics***  
For a more measure-theoretic, modern asymptotic approach, covering LAN theory, MLE, efficiency, and empirical process methods.

---

## 2. Frequentist & Classical Inference (Applied but Still Mathematical)

**Mood, Alexander M., Graybill, Franklin A., & Boes, Duane C. – *Introduction to the Theory of Statistics***  
An older classic—less measure theory, more probability calculus, with clear examples and derivations. Good for building intuition.

**Hogg, Robert V., McKean, Joseph W., & Craig, Allen T. – *Introduction to Mathematical Statistics***  
Another standard graduate text, with clear coverage of sampling distributions, estimation, and hypothesis testing. Accessible yet mathematically solid.

---

## 3. Bayesian Statistics (Foundations to Advanced)

**Bernardo, José M. & Smith, Adrian F. M. – *Bayesian Theory***  
A mathematically rigorous foundation of Bayesian inference, including decision-theoretic grounding, reference priors, and asymptotics.

**Robert, Christian P. – *The Bayesian Choice***  
Covers Bayesian decision theory, model comparison, computational techniques (MCMC, importance sampling), and asymptotic properties.

**Gelman, Andrew et al. – *Bayesian Data Analysis*** (BDA3)  
Less formal than Bernardo–Smith or Robert, but comprehensive in applied Bayesian modeling. Covers hierarchical models, computation, diagnostics, and applied case studies.

**Ghosh, Jayanta K., Delampady, Mohan, & Samanta, Tapas – *An Introduction to Bayesian Analysis: Theory and Methods***  
A mathematically precise introduction to Bayesian methods, covering both theoretical foundations and computational methods.

---

## 4. Additional References for Specialized Topics

**Schervish, Mark J. – *Theory of Statistics***  
Measure-theoretic, rigorous, and wide-ranging—covers both frequentist and Bayesian perspectives.

**O’Hagan, Anthony & Forster, Jonathan – *Kendall’s Advanced Theory of Statistics, Volume 2B: Bayesian Inference***  
Part of the Kendall series; highly technical Bayesian treatment.

**Berger, James O. – *Statistical Decision Theory and Bayesian Analysis***  
Connects Bayesian and frequentist decision-theoretic approaches with a solid mathematical backbone.

---

If you want, I can also **design a structured reading progression** that starts with probability prerequisites, moves into classical inference, then introduces Bayesian theory in a mathematically coherent order. This would ensure you cover both perspectives deeply and without redundancy.
